_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ral purpose of the MRUs is to dehydrate and liquefy natural gas from the gas stream. The field gas stream enters the MRU to condense the liquids in a closed loop system by physical separation and cryogenic means. Once the NGLs are condensed to approximately 25 degrees, then the liquids flow to the any of the four pressurized storage tanks onsite. These tanks are a part of the closed loop system. From there, the NGLs will be loaded out via truck.

The stored NGL product is considered a flammable mixture of methane, ethane, propane, iso-butane, n butane, iso-pentane, and n-pentane (C1-C5), with the primary components being propane and n-butane. In addition to the NGL storage from the MRUs, the site will have propane storage.

ite receptor has not been impacted by an accident in the previous five years as well. This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:

	A description of our facility and use of substances regulated by EPA's RMP regulation
	An overview of our accidental release prevention policies and programs
	A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals regulated by EPA's RMP rule
	An overview of our emergency response polices and program
	An overview of planned improvements at the facility to help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring and adversely affecting our employees, the public, and the environment 
	A summary of results from our assessment of the potential offsite consequences from accidental chemical releases
	The certifications that EPA's RMP rule requires us to provide
	The detailed information (called data elements) about our risk management program

The health and safety of facility personnel along with the surrounding community is a top priority in the design, construction, and operation of the Forland facility. Furthermore, Oasis Petroleum North America, LLC strives to be a leader in environmental responsibility and is determined to make a positive impact on the community. It is our policy to comply with the safety, health, and environmental laws and regulations applicable to our business.  

Upon placing this facility into operation, the site will be a continuously manned operation with operations personnel onsite at all times. They will be supported by the Environmental, Health and Safety Department, the Regulatory Department, and the company as a whole. Our companies are committed to compliance regarding applicable industry standards, federal regulations, and State and local requirements. 

FORLAND 5198 41-33 HL CENTRAL TANK BATTERY PROCESS DESCRIPTION

The gene

Oasis Petroleum North America, LLC owns and operates upstream and midstream assets in over 506,000 net acres of the Williston Basin for the Bakken, Three Forks and other horizons. It is an independent exploration and production company focused on the acquisition and development of unconventional oil and natural gas resources from an integrated perspective. Companies such as Oasis Petroleum North America, LLC play a vital role in the global oil and gas industry as it is at the forefront of technology deployment, operational efficiencies, and infrastructure development.  

Oasis Midstream Partners serves as a fundamental business that takes natural gas and crude oil retrieved in the upstream sector to the downstream processing facilities.  Thus, supporting activities that take place after the initial production phase and through to the point of sale. 

Oasis Midstream Partners (OMP) will operate the applicable facility titled the Forland 5198 41-33 HL Central Tank Battery (Forland) in McKenzie County, North Dakota.  Forland's purpose is to extract natural gas liquids (NGLs) from the field gas gathered from the nearby area of the Bakken Shale Formation. This extraction will be done using Mechanical Refrigeration Unit (MRU) skids. Additionally, the site will have propane storage. The facility's location is approximately 3.8 miles north-northeast of Watford City in McKenzie County, North Dakota.

The Forland location is required to develop and implement a proper Risk Management Program (RMP) to mitigate risk under the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) regulation for Chemical Accident Release Prevention (40 CFR 68).  This requirement is fulfilled with the onset of the listed chemicals (as identified onsite) above their individual threshold quantities.  As a Program 1 Level facility, it has been determined that the site is subject to the regulation and the covered processes will not affect the public in a worst-case release scenario.
